case_name: Religious head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community v. Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 99 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 20th August 1952 of Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 43 of 1952 arising out of Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 20th August, 1952, of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 43 of 1952 arising out of Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949.

facts.text: On February 28,1934, the Appellant who is the religious head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community, passed an order excommunicating one Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha.

anchor.surface_text: On February 28,1934, the Appellant who is the religious head of the Dawoodi Bohra Community, passed an order excommunicating one Tyebbhai Moosaji Koicha.

facts.text: On July 17, 1920, the appellant had excommunicated two persons, Tahirbhai and Hasan Ali.

anchor.surface_text: On July 17, 1920, the appellant had excommunicated two persons, Tahirbhai and Hasan Ali, and the validity of the order was questioned in a suit...

facts.text: Validity of 1920 excommunication order questioned in suit in Court of Subordinate Judge, Barhampur, went to Privy Council.

anchor.surface_text: ...and the validity of the order was questioned in a suit instituted in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Barhampur. The litigation went up to the Privy Council...

facts.text: Privy Council held appellant as religious head had power to excommunicate but only after observing requisite formalities; 1920 order invalid as formalities not observed. Vide Hasan Ali v. Mansoorali.

anchor.surface_text: ...which held that the appellant as the religious head had the power to excommunicate a member of the community, but that that power could only be exercised after observing the requisite formalities...

facts.text: On April 28, 1948, appellant passed another order of excommunication against Tyebbhai Moosaji.

anchor.surface_text: ...the appellant started fresh proceedings, and on April 28, 1948, passed another order of excommunication.

facts.text: Tyebbhai Moosaji filed suit Original Suit No. 1262 of 1949 for declaration that excommunication orders of 1934 and 1948 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, Tyebbhai Moosaji filed the present suit for a declaration that both the orders of excommunication dated February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were invalid...

facts.text: Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act (Bombay XLII of 1949) passed, came into force on November 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: While this action was pending, the Legislature of the Province of Bombay passed the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act Bombay XLII of 1949 prohibiting excommunication, and that came into force on November 1, 1949.

facts.text: Plaintiff contended that Bombay Act 1949 rendered excommunication orders illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff contended that the effect of this legislation was to render the orders of excommunication illegal.

facts.text: Appellant contended Act had no retrospective operation, orders of 1934 and 1948 valid and unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of the appellant to this contention was, firstly, that the Act had no retrospective operation, and that, in consequence, the orders passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid...

facts.text: Appellant contended Bombay Act unconstitutional as not covered by List 2 or 3 Seventh Schedule GOI Act 1935, Provincial Legislature lacked competence.

anchor.surface_text: ...and secondly, that the Act was itself unconstitutional, because the subject matter of the impugned legislation was not covered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935...

facts.text: After Constitution, contention raised that right to excommunicate protected by Arts. 25 and 26, Act void.

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Constitution, the contention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution...

facts.text: Issue No. 19: Whether orders of excommunication 1934 and/or 1948 invalid by reason of Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The issues in the action were then settled, and issue No. 19, which was raised with reference to the above contentions, was as follows Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid...

facts.text: Issue 19 tried as preliminary issue, State of Bombay impleaded as second defendant.

anchor.surface_text: ...This was tried as a preliminary issue, and as it raised the question of the vires of a statute, the State of Bombay was impleaded as the second defendant in the suit.

facts.text: Shah J held Act retrospective, within competence of Provincial Legislature, does not offend Arts 25 and 26.

anchor.surface_text: Shah J.who tried this issue, held that the impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, that it was within the competence of the Provincial Legislature, and further that it did not offend Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal to Bombay High Court heard by Chagla C.J. and Bhagwati J., held excommunication is continuous state, Act operates from its date, within competence, no infringement of Arts 25/26, dismissed appeal, granted certificate under Arts 132/133.

anchor.surface_text: Against this finding, the present appellant preferred an appeal to a Bench of the Bombay High Court, and that was heard by Chagla C. J. and Bhagwati J. who held that under the Act, excommunication meant the condition of being expelled...

facts.text: Plaintiff died on March 11, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal, the plaintiff died on March 11, 1953,...

facts.text: Daughter of plaintiff applied on May 22, 1953 to be substituted, did not press, dismissed on October 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: ...and his daughter applied on May 22, 1953, to be substituted in his place. But eventually she did not press the application, and that was dismissed on October 5, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court order dated November 21, 1955 amended cause title by deleting name of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court by an order dated November 21, 1955, the cause title was amended by deleting the name of the plaintiff.

facts.text: No decree passed in suit, only finding on preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: It should be remembered in this connection that no decree had been passed in the suit. Only a finding has been given on a preliminary point...

facts.text: Suit abated on death of plaintiff as actio personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate.

facts.text: Appeal not maintainable under Art. 132 as no decree or final order, only finding on issue.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of opinion that the appeal is not competent under Art. 132, and the fact that a certificate has been given does not alter the position.
the Legislature of the Province of Bombay passed the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act  Bombay XLII of 1949  prohibiting excommunication, and that came into force on November 1, 1949.

concepts.unlisted_description: Whether Act applies to past orders

issues.text: Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid by reason of the provisions of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act of 1949?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the orders of excommunication made in 1934 and or 1948 are invalid by reason of the A.I.R. 1948 P.C. 66. 1010 provisions of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act of 1949?

issues.text: Whether the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 had retrospective operation such that the orders of excommunication dated February 28, 1934 and April 28, 1948 were invalid?

anchor.surface_text: the Act had no retrospective operation, and that, in consequence, the orders passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid,

issues.text: Whether the subject matter of the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 was covered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935 giving the Provincial Legislature competence?

anchor.surface_text: the Act was itself unconstitutional, because the subject matter of the impugned legislation was not covered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935,

issues.text: Whether the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution making the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act void?

anchor.surface_text: the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution,

issues.text: Whether the suit abated on the death of the plaintiff on the principle actio personalis moritur cum persona?

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate.

issues.text: Whether the appeal can proceed after abatement of the suit and deletion of the plaintiff?

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the only parties who are now before the Court are the defendant and the State of Bombay. The question is whether in the events which have happened, the appeal can proceed.

issues.text: Whether the appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State of Bombay to challenge the vires of the Act following the abatement of the suit, as in United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant argues that as the State of Bombay had been impleaded as a party, and that as the decision on the question of the vires of the Act had been given in its presence, the appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State without reference to the plaintiff and seek the decision of this Court on the validity of the Act and relies on the decision of the Federal Court in The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others

issues.text: Whether an appeal lies to this Court under Art. 132 against the finding on the preliminary issue?

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 132, an appeal lies to this Court only against judgments, decrees or final orders. That was also the position under s. 205 of the Government of India Act.

issues.text: Whether the finding on the preliminary issue is a final order under the Explanation to Art. 132?

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case. Applying this test, even if we accept the contention of the appellant that the impugned Act is bad, that would not finally dispose of the suit,

issues.text: Whether a certificate under Art. 133 can be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding on a preliminary issue?

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the certificate is also under Art. 133, but under that article also, an appeal lies Only against judgments, decrees or final orders, and no certificate could be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding.

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 renders the orders of excommunication dated February 28, 1934 and April 28, 1948 illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff contended that the effect of this legislation was to render the orders of excommunication illegal.

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 has no retrospective operation and therefore the orders of excommunication dated February 28, 1934 and April 28, 1948 remain valid and unaffected.

anchor.surface_text: The answer of the appellant to this contention was, firstly, that the Act had no retrospective operation, and that, in consequence, the orders passed on February 28, 1934, and April 28, 1948, were valid,...

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 is unconstitutional as its subject matter is not covered by any entries in List 2 or 3 of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935 and the Provincial Legislature lacked competence.

anchor.surface_text: ...and secondly, that the Act was itself unconstitutional, because the subject matter of the impugned legislation was not covered by any of the entries in List 2 or 3 of Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935,...

arguments.claim: The right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community is protected by Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution making the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act void.

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Constitution, the contention was also raised that the right of the defendant to excommunicate members of the community was protected by Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution,...

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 is retrospective in its operation.

anchor.surface_text: Shah J.who tried this issue, held that the impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, that it was within the competence of the Provincial Legislature,...

arguments.claim: Under the Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949, excommunication means the condition of being expelled which is a continuous state depriving the excommunicated of rights and privileges, so the Act operates from its date of commencement.

anchor.surface_text: ...who held that under the Act, excommunication meant the condition of being expelled, that it was a continuous state during which the person excommunicated was deprived of his rights and privileges, and that, therefore, the Act would operate...

arguments.claim: The Bombay Prevention of Excommunication Act 1949 is within the competence of the Provincial Legislature and does not offend Articles 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Shah J.who tried this issue, held that the impugned Act was retrospective in its operation, that it was within the competence of the Provincial Legislature, and further that it did not offend Arts. 25 and 26 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State of Bombay alone to challenge the vires of the Act as the State was impleaded and decision given in its presence, following the precedent in United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. N. C. Chatterjee for the appellant argues that as the State of Bombay had been impleaded as a party, and that as the decision on the question of the vires of the Act had been given in its presence, the appellant is entitled to continue the appeal against the State without reference to the plaintiff...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t itself impleaded as a party to the appeal of the landlord, and a decision having been given therein in accordance with the opinion of the Full Bench

arguments.court_reasoning: The ruling in Atiqa Begum does not apply as there was a decree and the suit had not abated; here the suit has abated entirely and there is no decree.

arguments.claim: The suit abated on the death of the plaintiff without substitution as it is actio personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate.

arguments.claim: There can be no appeal as it is a continuation of the suit and the suit has abated.

anchor.surface_text: Here, the action itself has abated, and there can be no question of an appeal in relation thereto, as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit, and there can be no question of continuing what does not exist.

arguments.claim: The decision in United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum does not apply as there was a decree satisfying s. 205 GOI Act whereas here there is no decree or final order and the suit has abated.

anchor.surface_text: This ruling has, in our opinion, no application to the facts of the present case. Here, the action itself has abated... In The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others supra , there was a decree, and the requirements of s. 205 were satisfied.

arguments.claim: No appeal lies under Article 132 as the order is only a finding on a preliminary issue, not a judgment, decree or final order.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 132, an appeal lies to this Court only against judgments, decrees or final orders. That was also the position under s. 205 of the Government of India Act. Now, the order appealed against is only a decision on one of the issues, and it does not dispose of the suit.

arguments.claim: The finding is not a final order under the Explanation to Article 132 as even if the Act is held invalid it would not suffice for final disposal of the suit due to other issues.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case. Applying this test, even if we accept the contention of the appellant that the impugned Act is bad, that would not finally dispose of the suit,...

arguments.claim: No certificate under Article 133 can validate the appeal as it requires judgments, decrees or final orders and cannot cover an interlocutory finding.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the certificate is also under Art. 133, but under that article also, an appeal lies Only against judgments, decrees or final orders, and no certificate could be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding.

holdings.text: The suit abated upon the death of the plaintiff without substitution as it is an action personalis moritur cum persona.

anchor.surface_text: On the principle, actio personalis moritur cum persona when he died the suit should abate. As a matter of fact, his legal representative applied to be brought on record, but the application was not pressed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The claim for declaration that plaintiff was wrongly excommunicated is personal to him; upon death without substitution, suit abates.

holdings.text: The appeal cannot proceed after abatement of the suit as an appeal is a continuation of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the suit has abated. This would ordinarily entail the dismissal of this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: With suit abated, there is no suit to continue via appeal.

holdings.text: The appellant is not entitled to continue the appeal against the State of Bombay alone to challenge the vires of the Act; United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: This ruling has, in our opinion, no application to the facts of the present case. Here, the action itself has abated, and there can be no question of an appeal in relation thereto, as an appeal is only a continuation of the suit,

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Atiqa Begum, there was a decree and suit had not abated; here suit abated entirely, no decree exists.

holdings.text: No appeal lies under Article 132 as the order is only a finding on a preliminary issue, not a judgment, decree or final order.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 132, an appeal lies to this Court only against judgments, decrees or final orders. That was also the position under s. 205 of the Government of India Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order does not dispose of the suit; remains undetermined with other issues pending.

holdings.text: The finding on the preliminary issue is not a final order under the Explanation to Article 132.

anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if Act held invalid, would not finally dispose of suit due to other issues to be tried.

holdings.text: No certificate under Article 133 can be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding on a preliminary issue.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that the certificate is also under Art. 133, but under that article also, an appeal lies Only against judgments, decrees or final orders, and no certificate could be granted in respect of an interlocutory finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 133 also requires judgments, decrees or final orders.

holdings.text: The appeal is not maintainable and must be dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of abatement, lack of decree/final order, and invalid certificates.

holdings.text: This order expresses no opinion on the correctness of the decision under appeal and does not preclude the appellant from claiming rights in appropriate proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express no opinion on the correctness of the decision under appeal, this order will not preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cautionary note to clarify scope of dismissal.

Mansoorali supra on the ground that it had number companyplied with the requisite formalities, the appellant started fresh proceedings, and on April 28, 1948,

precedents.cited_proposition: the appellant as the religious head had the power to excommunicate a member of the companymunity, but that that power companyld only be exercised after observing the requisite formalities, and as in that case that had number been done, the order of excommunication was invalid

precedents.citation: The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others 1

anchor.surface_text: The United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others 1 . There, a suit was filed by a landlord for recovery of rent. While it was pending in appeal, an Act was passed by the Legislature of the United Provinces validating certain Government numberifications requiring the landlords to give to the tenants remission of rent. The landlord companytended that the Act was ultra vires,

precedents.case_name: United Provinces v. Mst. Atiqa Begum and others
precedents.cited_proposition: the Government was entitled to file the appeal for getting a decision on the validity of the Act, notwithstanding that it had number interest in the claim in the suit
precedents.cited_holding: scope of s. 205 of the Government of India Act was wider than that of s. 96 of the Civil Procedure Code, and that the Government was entitled to file the appeal

justification_sets.label: actio personalis moritur cum persona support
Section 205, Government of India Act, 1935 support

anchor.surface_text: The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as not maintainable because the suit abated upon the death of the plaintiff without substitution and there is no decree or final order against which appeal lies under Articles 132 or 133 of the Constitution.
directions: This order will not preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 132, an appeal lies to this Court only against judgments, decrees or final orders. That was also the position under s. 205 of the Government of India Act.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable. anchor.surface_text: The Explanation to Art. 132 provides that For the purposes of this Article, the expression final order includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case.

The result is that this appeal must be dismissed, as not maintainable. We should add by way of abundant caution that as we express numberopinion on the 1013 companyrectness of the decision under appeal, this order will number preclude the appellant from claiming such rights as he may have, in appropriate proceedings which he may take.
